key_points: Republicans in the U.S. Senate blocked a bipartisan inquiry into the Capitol riot on Jan. 6 by former President Donald Trump's supporters.
The vote for the commission was 54-35, falling short of the 60 needed to advance the legislation.
All 35 no votes were cast by Republicans, with six Republicans voting in favor of the commission.
Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer criticized the Republicans for defending Trump to avoid political repercussions.
The proposed commission would have been able to subpoena witnesses, including possibly Trump, to testify under oath.
This marks the first use in 2021 of the filibuster to defeat legislation in the Senate.
The White House stated President Joe Biden's commitment to a full, independent investigation of the attack.
Senate Republican Leader Mitch McConnell argued that a commission would duplicate existing efforts and possibly focus undue attention on Trump and the 2020 election controversies.
Senator Susan Collins, who voted for the commission, attempted to negotiate amendments requiring bipartisan commission staff appointments.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Democrats would “proceed to find the truth” despite the Senate vote, without detailing how.
